Description: Terracotta female figure. Head fragment of a woman wearing a high decorated head-dress of the stephane or kalathos type covered with raised ornamentation. The mouth is naturalistic and the eyes are poorly modelled. Mould-made and hollow. Formerly covered with a white coating, this now remains as traces. Fine light yellow to pinkish brown clay.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

'Careless work of the last half of the fourth century or even later' (Gutch 1898-9, 80, no.20), though the register lists a late 5th century BC date. '59' is written on the piece in pencil, possibly a find location. Parallels from Salamis, Cyprus (Monloup 1994, nos 164, 168, 172, 178). Monloup, T. 1994. Salamine de Chypre. 14, Les terres cuites classiques: un sanctuaire de la grande déesse. Paris: Diffusion de Boccard.
Bibliographic references: Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 80, no. 20)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DA.108) (Phase 3)
